awd_titl_txt: Tailoring the Nanophotonic and Nanoelectronic Properties of Nanometals using Oxide-Directed Syntheses
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Svetlana Neretina of the University of Notre Dame will investigate how oxides can be used to control the growth of metal nanoparticles on substrates with spatial registration. Improvements in the understanding of metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms are expected to result in new synthetic strategies for nanostructure templating that could be exploited for applications in active plasmonics, nanoelectronics, and chiral plasmonics. Dr. Neretina is actively involved in the Building Bridges Mentoring Program and the Advancing Women Leaders Program as well several outreach initiatives that focus on the development of in-lab high school research projects. These activities open up opportunities for Dr. Neretina and her group to actively engage students in areas that are not typically covered in standard curricula.

This research involves the advancement of a liquid-state seed-mediated chemistry for the syntheses of on-chip metal nanostructures that are responsive to the synthetic controls imposed by an impinging oxide. Oxides that steer horizontal Au nanowire growth trajectories along deterministic pathways that self-terminate upon an encounter with an electrode, confine plasmonic nanostructures within liquid-filled oxide capsules where their resulting mobility makes them responsive to externally applied stimuli, and selectively react in liquid media are exploited. This approach builds on traditional chemical controls that are accessible through colloidal syntheses and physical controls that are obtainable when a growing metal encounters a chemically inert oxide barrier that is firmly affixed to the substrate surface. By exploiting the synthetic inactivity and passive behavior of oxides to impose steric barriers that act in opposition to or frustrate the natural tendencies associated with nanometal syntheses, the research team seeks to produce reaction products that are typically unobtainable. The work will leverage existing capabilities stemming from a synthetic strategy in which seed-mediated colloidal growth modes are practiced on periodic arrays of substrate immobilized seeds.  Overall, this research seeks to develop oxide-directed solution-based chemistry that targets the formation of organized surfaces of nanomaterials with tailored nanoelectronic and nanophotonic properties.  Reduction to practice of such an approach to constructing organized surfaces with tailored properties would likely have broad scientific impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The MSN Award advanced the techniques and knowhow for forming metal nanostructures on planar surfaces for on-chip applications. The synthetic schemes forwarded were unique in that high-level control over nanometal synthesis was achieved by using oxides as a means to steer synthesis to the desired endpoints. It resulted in the forwarding of procedures that addressed the long-standing synthetic challenge of forming large-area periodic arrays of triangular gold and silver nanoplates. Such nanomaterials are renowned for their ability to strongly interact with light. Also achieved was a first-of-its-kind nanofabrication procedure in which dual-component nanostructures of gold and silver were produced in periodic arrays where each structure was identically aligned on the substrate. These nanomaterials, which are commonly referred to as Janus structures after the two-faced Roman God, express optical and photochemical properties that are distinct from their component materials. The project was also successful in advancing processes that gave rise to hybrid nanostructures comprised of metal and oxide segments. These achievements were disseminated in six publications in prestigious journals as well as in nine invited and three contributed talks at internationally attended conferences that include the American Chemical Society and Materials Research Society Meetings. The article published in Small was notably selected for the Women in Materials Science Virtual Issue that showcases "outstanding works created, steered, and led by women scientists" that appear in one of Wiley's leading material science journals.

Broader Impacts: Single and multicomponent nanostructures have become an indispensable class of materials with applications in catalysis, sensing, biomedicine, plasmonics, environmental remediation, and photovoltaic energy production, storage, and chemical conversion. With the site-selective deposition of oxides on metal nanostructures proving crucial to many of these applications, the work has advanced the techniques and knowhow required for a nanostructure-by-design modality in which predicted application-specific properties motivate syntheses directed toward obtaining the designed structure. With substrate-based single-crystal noble metal nanostructures increasingly being recognized as a highly desirable platform for on-chip applications, this work has also advanced the core competencies related to the organized positioning of nanometric building blocks over large areas. Broader Impact has also been achieved through efforts directed toward the organization of symposiums at three leading material science conferences that provide venues for disseminating leading-edge research and networking. Highlights in terms of student achievement, mentorship, and service include: (i) graduate student Robert Neal receiving the Notre Dame Integrated Imaging Facility's 2022 Award for Best Electron Beam Imaging Publication, (ii) graduate student Walker Tuff receiving the Materials Science and Engineering Ph.D. program's 2023 Outstanding Paper Award, (iii) three conference presentations by graduate students, (iv) two completed Ph.D. dissertations where these graduates are now employed at the Department of Defense and Faraday Technology, Inc, (v) mentorship of four undergraduate research internships and three award-winning high-school science fair projects, and (vi) numerous contributions in terms of outreach, service to the Notre Dame community, and in advancing a culture of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion.
